newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK residential mortgages up 1.8pct on month in Nov.
newsitem.headline: HK residential mortgages up 1.8pct on month in Nov.

text.p: The volume of residential mortgage loans in Hong Kong continued to grow rapidly in November, confirming a recovery in property market, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) said on Monday.
The HKMA said total outstanding mortgage lending by the 33 institutions in the survey rose 1.8 percent on the month to HK$319.9 billion, against October's 2.0 percent increase.
The growth rate remained higher than the monthly average of 1.5 percent over the last twelve months, it said in a statement.

New loans approved during the month was the highest since the survey was first conducted in December, 1992, but it was offset by a corresponding increase in the amount of repayments which rose by 18.2 percent to HK$11.2 billion, HKMA said.

"These figures reflect the revival of refinancing of existing mortgages as well as demand for new mortgages arising from the continued buoyant residential property market in October," HKMA acting deputy chief executive Raymond Li said.

The annualised rate of growth in lending over the last three months increased to 20.1 percent from 14.7 percent in the three-month period to October, while the twelve-month average of outstanding loans showed an annualised increase of 17.6 percent from October's 17.0 percent, it said.
Lending for purchase of properties in China increased by 1.1 percent to HK$6.0 billion in November.
